John Miller is wrong yet again. Twice.

(1) The reactor at Chernobyl was graphite moderated with a positive void coefficient, making it a bit dangerous to operate. The operators did something which was clearly *forbidden* in their manual of operation. Boom!

(2) Sodium cooled reactors are fast reactors, unmoderated. The sodium is far below the temperature of vaporization and in any case the liquid sodium does not moderate.

Dr K writes, "everything I’ve seen indicates that members of the Republican elite still don’t get the basics of health reform."

He gives them too much credit. The Republican elite are smart guys. If they say things demonstrating stupid, it is not because they are stupid. It is because they refuse to admit what they know is true.

Health care for all Americans will mean more doctors, nurses, and health care facilities. There are tens of millions of people who don't get those things now. If they do, those things will have to be paid for. The Republican elite don't want to do it.

That is not to say we will spend more on health care overall. Right now the extra that is spent to deny claims, and avoid care, and overprice care, all goes to -- guess it now -- that same Republican elite.

Providing health care for our health care dollar would take those dollars from people who now get them for NOT providing health care. It is very profitable. They want to keep that money.

As for health care, they have golden plans far better than any we are ever likely to see. The lifetime plan for any Congress-critter who serves even one term is just an example of a huge abuse. They don't want to share their health care either.

They get the basics. They are just greedy. It is just plain greed, disguised as stupid.

The US government health-care sector already taxes and spends 7% of our money, just like Britain and Canada.  Why isn't it already giving us what they have, with out extra private spending as a bonus?   If our tax-paid health care is only half as effective as theirs, why should we expand ours?

it is pretty obvious that key parts of the Republican party want to continue making huge profits off private health insurance forever like Florida's gov Rick Scott who ran such an outfit found guilty of major fraud. Or like former Senate Republican Leader Bill Frist whose family made their fortune on privatized healthcare...

What is more baffling is why other Corporations like GM, Ford, and those NOT in the private insurance business have allowed themselves to be forced to pay tribute to these profiteers. For example, GM's largest expense was healthcare which was one reason some key car production got moved over to Windsor, Canada which was so much cheaper with single-payer...

How many potential small business entrepreneurs are afraid to launch solely into a small business due to the huge costs of healthcare for themselves and possibly their employees?

You must realize that most developed countries in the world, Canada included, have full-on, all-out, no-holds-barred socialized medicine.

It is much more than single-payer insurance - it is government control of the health care system.

The populations in these countries accept that, in fact they would not have it any other way.

But will that ever become the system in the US? I doubt it?

And will the US ever get its medical costs down to the level of the costs in these other countries? Not likely.

There are some other points that may prove problematic for "fiscally conservative" Republicans who pretend to abhor waste

1. All other major wealthy democracies have some form of national health insurance. In many of these countries political conservatives were initially opposed. (In Canada, the province of Saskatchewan was the first to bring universal coverage, and it survived an actual doctors' strike.) National health insurance is now so popular that no conservative party interested in survival would ever tamper with the basics of universal coverage.

2. Every other advanced democracy spends way, way less than the U.S. on health care, about an average of seven per cent of gdp less, or, for the U.S., over a trillion wasted. And Republicans pretend to be concerned about deficits--when they don't hold the presidency.

3. The trillion is doubly wasted since the overall health stats of the U.S. are worse than nearly all the wealthy democracies.

Why are Republicans so committed to a health care system that wastes a trillion for bad results? It could be that the rich who profit off obscene health care markups are big donors. It could be that the GOP is the party of the one per cent who never miss an opportunity to serve wealth, or hammer the poor.

And labor markets are more efficient when health care considerations do not form a major barrier to job mobility. Aren't the Republicans supposed to be the party of free markets?
Or maybe the Republicans are liars.

I agree completely, and the shortcomings of the Affordable Care Act (as important and beneficial as it is) are a major reason why health care--and, in particular, how can we can expand upon and improve upon the Affordable Care Act (by, for example, adding a public option)--should be a major issue in the 2016 Democratic primaries. The Affordable Care Act should be viewed not as the final culmination but as an important first step towards national universal health care security. And these shortcomings are also why nobody--and that includes Hilary Clinton--should be coronated the Democratic nominee in 2016.

And left out of this column by the good Doctor is the fact that the ACA was a creation of the right wing of the GOP, aka Heritage Foundation,and endorsed by the GOP, and implemented by their chosen presidential candidate when a state governor. Oops!

"This achievement will represent a huge defeat for the conservative agenda of weakening the safety net. And Republicans who deluded their supporters into believing that none of this would happen will probably pay a large personal price. But as I said, they have nobody but themselves to blame." --- Krugman

At least we can hope that those who have supported the Republicans will see it that way, but they've been fed (and are still being fed) so much "misinformation" about the Affordable Care Act that it may take a while for them to realize that the Act has some positive aspects. Not that it's ideal by any means; this cobbled together legislation is needlessly complicated, gives away too much to the health insurance industry and Big Pharma, and is apt to be a confusing mess to many people who don't have the time or inclination to learn about the details. In short, it's an improvement over the status quo, but the heartbreak is that it could have been so much better.

Other advanced nations have single payer systems, or at least have heavily regulated non-profit insurance companies. But single payer wasn't even considered when the ACA was being drawn up, and the opportunity to at least have a "public option," which would have eliminated some problems with the final bill, was dropped by President Obama himself, after he had previously declared that a public option was necessary to keep the insurance industry honest and hold down costs. Hopefully, the ACA is not the last word!

So--employers are dropping insurance: because they are rejecting cheaper premiums, and tax credits for small businesses?

Indiana's wildly inflated premium estimate averaged in the cost of platinum plans; when averaged against similar plans, the costs were lower. In fact, so far, all costs are lower. Why would an employer offering insurance drop a plan that reduces the employer's costs?

Read closely: Obamacare does not set payment rates. It sets coverage standards. The private insurers who will offer and sell those policies will determine, as they do now, the payments for each service or visit the doctor provides. If doctors are dealing with the insurers currently, and satisfied with their payment rates, why would they "leave" their practices?

As for "cash-only" medical practices, you suggest a false cause. The shift is driven by insurance complexity and payment practices (according to an AMA paper on practice management.). Several innovative forms of cash practices can be organized, but such a move is not being driven by the standards required under Obamacare. To suggest the connection is misleading.

Covering pre-existing conditions, ending lifetime limits, and extending insurance to 30 million doesn't constitute a "failure," before or after, for those who recall the American promise was also one of compassion.

What do you mean when you state that Congress and its staffers are not required to participate in Obamacare?  Don't all members of Congress and their staff have employer-provided health insurance?  Obamacare requires all Americans to have insurance, whether provided by employer, Medicaid, or individually purchased.  Seems to me that Congress is already in compliance, as am I, as are you if you have employer-provided health insurance.
big business is the group raping America.....and the Republican leadership represents it.

" the employer mandate is a fairly minor add-on that arguably shouldn’t have been in the law to begin with." Yet it IS part of the law, but somehow President Obama has dumped it. As he dumped the provision requiring Congress and its staffers to participate in Obamacare, the provision mandating means qualification for individual subsidies (dropped as the IRS claims it's unable to verify income!), the provision capping the combined out-of-pocket care and out-of-pocket medication (they will now be capped separately), and numerous other Obamacare regulations that the President, without any legal authority, is setting aside. That doesn't even include the thousands of (legal) waivers already issued by Secretary Kathleen Sebelius to union friends, corporate cronies, and well-connected universities and municipalities.

The reform is already divided, with Obama's pals getting special deals while ordinary Americans see their jobs converted to part-time, their employers dropping insurance or raising deductibles and co-pays, and doctors leaving their practices or shifting to a cash-only (no insurance, please) basis. This is one reform that has failed even before it is put in place.
